{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2991360,"name":"Jim simpson","username":"JSIMPSO","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e9a140/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T05:56:51.503Z","cooked":"

In preparation for some control system / programming training, I put together this Romi simulation. (Our real Romi isn’t quite ready for use yet.) It uses the “state space” differential drive train simulation and the underlying “json” style protocol between the robot code running on a PC and the simulated Romi. Drive motors, encoders, gyro, and some of the switch/LED digitals are all simulated.

The robot code needs to point to the IP address of the PC running the simulator, or 127.0.0.1 if using the same PC for both.

Here is a picture of the simulation. The Romi is highlighted since it is very small, compared with the field, even though it is slightly larger than its real life counterpart.

romi-sim-field1179×946 477 KB

I made some observations and questions about the Romi along the way.

  • The motor modeling parameters appear to be taken after the gearbox. So, the gear ratio for the simulation ends up being 1:1. Only the encoder scaling needs the actual gear ratio.
  • I think that the gyro reads in continuous degrees incrementing counter clockwise. (If not, this is easy to change).
  • I didn’t take the time to look at the schematic, but I wasn’t certain if the switch B,C interacted with the LEDS on the same DIO, or are hardware switch selectable. The simulation doesn’t do anything with the switches except when they change state.
  • I’d expect the simulator to be language agnostic, since it interprets the same protocol intended for the Raspberry PI.
  • I guessed at the battery resistance. The original is 0.02 ohm, but it may need to closer to 0.3 ohm. Thoughts?
  • Neither the accelerometer or the optional arm are simulated. If a robot code tries to use these, nothing bad should happen. Just nothing will happen.

To use the simulation:

  • Open the simulation project and run the simulation. This can run on the same PC as the robot code or a different PC, as long as any firewall has port 3300 open between the two computers.
  • Open the driver station, and optionally the dashboard. I believe these need to run on the same PC as the robot code.
  • Open the robot project and set the IP address of the Romi to the IP address of the simulation. (Use 127.0.0.1 if running everything on the same PC.)
  • Select enable on the drivers station and test your robot code.

In case this is useful to other teams, I added the simulation project to this repository. (Under the directory FRC_Romi_Simulation)

GitHub

GitHub - jsimpso81/WPIlibMathLabVIEW_Examples: FRC LabVIEW Control /...

FRC LabVIEW Control / Trajectory Library Utilities and Samples - GitHub - jsimpso81/WPIlibMathLabVIEW_Examples: FRC LabVIEW Control / Trajectory Library Utilities and Samples

Happy roboting.
